description: In this tutorial animation, we explain how to calculate the energy reaction profile and activation barrier for the multi-dimensional energy space of chemical reactions via the Nudged Elastic Bands (NEB) method, as implemented under Quantum ESPRESSO. In this case, we make use of a manually-generated interpolated set of intermediate images.
title: Exabyte.io Tutorial: Calculate Reaction Profile Using the Nudged Elastic Band (NEB) method

youTubeCaptions.text: Create a simulation, by navigating to the job designer page.
Then, <break time='0.5' /> open the materials tab, and choose the entire Interpolated Set by selecting all five images of the hydrogen molecule in the example list.

Then, <break time='0.5' /> open the workflow tab, and choose the 'Nudged Elastic Band' workflow by selecting it in the list. <break time='0.5' /> This workflow can be imported from the bank, if it is not already listed.

We now navigate to the 'Important Settings' tab, where we set the size of the grid of k-points to one for all image structures within the interpolated set, since we are dealing with chemical molecules in this case.
Finally, we look at the main N.E.B. subworkflow, and inspect its only unit.

Within the Quantum ESPRESSO input script at the bottom, pay particular attention to the list of initial, intermediate, and final image structures, contained in the interpolated set under consideration.
After that, <break time='0.5' /> navigate to compute tab, and set compute configuration. Here, we use one node with four cores.
Then, <break time='0.5' /> set the name for the job. <break time='2.0' /> Here, we call it - Quantum ESPRESSO N.E.B. Calculation.
Next, <break time='0.5' /> save the job. <break time='5.0' /> It can then be selected and submitted to the compute queue, for execution. <break time='4.0' />
The status of the calculation will change from pre-submitted to submitted, and then to active.
When the job is finished, open it, to inspect the final results.

The final result for the plot of the reaction energy profile, as a function of the overall reaction coordinate, can be found under the results page. <break time='1.0' /> The correct activation energy barrier for the collinear proton transfer reaction in hydrogen, of around 0.2 eV, has been computed.

We conclude this tutorial by navigating to the account-owned Materials collection. Here, a new folder called initial/final structures is created automatically at the end of the N.E.B. run. Inside it, the image structures of the interpolated set, before and after relaxation, can be retrieved and inspected.
